title: Tutorial 01
section: Exercise 3 — Create a derived column (with setup)
text:
Exercise 3 — Create a derived column (with setup)
Create df$ratio equal to mpg / hp in mtcars, then preview it.














df$ratio <- df$mpg / df$hp
head(df$ratio)
df$ratio <- df$mpg / df$hp
head(df$ratio)

title: Tutorial 01
text:
How to use this page

Edit the code in each exercise and click Run Code.
Click Check Answer for instant feedback.
Use Show hint / Show solution as needed.
Your edits persist in the browser.

title: Tutorial 01
text:
Q2 — Write a function
Make double(x) return 2 * x. Keep the function name the same.
Behavior is graded, so x*2 and 2*x are both accepted.

title: Tutorial 01
text:
Edit the code in each exercise, click Run Code, then Check Answer.
“Soft blanks” use a placeholder so you don’t get parse errors.
Grading is behavior-based (no gradethis needed).

title: Tutorial 01
Tutorial 01
section: Q3 — Draw a histogram from cars
text:
Q3 — Draw a histogram from cars
Make a histogram using a numeric column from cars.
Valid: hist(cars$dist), hist(cars$speed), with(cars, hist(speed)), hist(cars[["dist"]]), hist(cars[, "speed"]), hist(cars[, 2]).














hist(cars$dist)
hist(cars$dist)

title: Tutorial 01
section: Q3 — Draw a histogram from cars (type the full call)
text:
Q3 — Draw a histogram from cars (type the full call)
Use exactly one of these numeric columns and nothing else:
dist or speed











hist(cars$dist)
hist(cars$dist)

title: Tutorial 01
section: Q2 — Write a function using division
text:
Q2 — Write a function using division
Define a function called divide_nums that takes two arguments (a and b) and returns the results of:

a / b

b / a

Both results should be stored in separate variables before being returned.






Info



Remember: in R, division by zero (1/0) will return Inf rather than an error.








Info



In R, lists are written with list(a, b, c). Each element can be anything: a number, a string, or even another list.











Start with: res1 <- a / b res2 <- b / a list(res1, res2)




divide_nums <- function(a, b) {
  res1 <- a / b
  res2 <- b / a
  list(res1, res2)
}
divide_nums <- function(a, b) {
  res1 <- a / b
  res2 <- b / a
  list(res1, res2)
}

Info

Q2 — Write a function using division
Define a function called divide_nums that takes two arguments (a and b) and returns the results of:

a / b

b / a

Both results should be stored in separate variables before being returned.






NoteInfo



Remember: in R, division by zero (1/0) will return Inf rather than an error.








NoteInfo



In R, lists are written with list(a, b, c). Each element can be anything: a number, a string, or even another list.











Start with: res1 <- a / b res2 <- b / a list(res1, res2)




divide_nums <- function(a, b) {
  res1 <- a / b
  res2 <- b / a
  list(res1, res2)
}
divide_nums <- function(a, b) {
  res1 <- a / b
  res2 <- b / a
  list(res1, res2)
}

title: Tutorial 01
text:
Q2 — Create a vector
Make a vector called my_vec that contains the numbers 5, 10, 15, 20.









Use the c() function to combine numbers: c(1, 2, 3)




my_vec <- c(5, 10, 15, 20)
my_vec <- c(5, 10, 15, 20)

title: Tutorial 01
section: Q4 — Write a function using division
text:
Q4 — Write a function using division
Define a function called divide_nums that takes two arguments (a and b) and returns the results of:

a / b

b / a

Both results should be stored in separate variables before being returned.






NoteInfo



Remember: in R, division by zero (1/0) will return Inf rather than an error.








NoteInfo



In R, lists are written with list(a, b, c). Each element can be anything: a number, a string, or even another list.











Start with: res1 <- a / b res2 <- b / a list(res1, res2)




divide_nums <- function(a, b) {
  res1 <- a / b
  res2 <- b / a
  list(res1, res2)
}
divide_nums <- function(a, b) {
  res1 <- a / b
  res2 <- b / a
  list(res1, res2)
}

title: Tutorial 01
text:
Q5 — Find the average
Compute the mean of the vector c(2, 4, 6, 8, 10).
Your answer should be stored in a variable called avg_val.









Use the mean() function: mean(c(…))




avg_val <- mean(c(2, 4, 6, 8, 10))
avg_val <- mean(c(2, 4, 6, 8, 10))
